topic.title: I've set up a permanant node. Now I want to start seeding.
topic.body: Zeronet downloads and seeds every zite I visit. Do I need to manually update the site? Or will they update automatically over time?

topic.title: ZeroNet convenience, Achievable even by the technically retarded.
topic.body:
I've got ZeroNet set up up and spinning on a dedicated box at home. Now, I can access it from anywhere at anytime using duckdns. 

I have a couple questions that I think are relevant going forward. Just how much space can I expect this to take if I leave it running for months (years?) on end. It seems that it's theoretically possible for the entirety of zeronet to eventually end up hosted by me locally depending on my usage habits. If we plan to grow, then the average user will eventually need to dedicate massive amounts of space to the network. I've got 100g dedicated, but it seems that if we grow, which we must, then eventually each normal user could need terabytes in order to make the network readily accessible to everyone. 
How is this being planned for? Is there any plan to perhaps make sure that old sites that haven't been updated for a long time (some threshold) are eventually pruned automatically? 

Second: I know ZeroNet has multi-user capability, which I think is great because it allows the average user to connect via proxy and experience zeronet without having to do their own install. But it begs the question; from the perspective of a normal internet user, what benefit do they reap from being here vs clearnet? All their friends are on clearnet. Their socials are on clearnet, their banking is on clearnet, their email is on clearnet... all the interesting meme video sites are on clearnet for heavens sake. 

How do we draw them? The answer I think is creative and interesting content. If zeronet is to be a place where oddballs such and me and (possibly you) congregate away from everyone else, then it will never be anything more than a bunker for the technically inclined. 

Why does content blossom and grow on clearnet? The answer I think is because the clearnet exists for one reason and one reason alone: To make money. Rarely is anything done that doesn't benefit someone financially. There are rare exceptions like 4chan (it doesn't make money, but it at least breaks even). Facebook exists for advertising, google is an advertising company. Even places like redding, deviant art, etc... they MAKE MONEY by advertising. They do it on the back of content creators, but they exist for advertising nonetheless. 

It seems like these things have a natural cycle to them: First people are genuinely interested in making content because it brings them joy to do so, eventually, they realize they can make money on it. They rarely do so by themselves... rather, its done through a system of advertisement, through subscription, syndication, etc. Either people get on board or they don't. Look at liveleak, it couldn't compete with youtube, it's hanging on by a thread now and it looks like a site from the late 90's. 

I guess my main concern is this: How to we get content creators interested in ZeroNet, how do we ensure they benefit from it , how can we drive traffic here, and ensure they stay here, and most importantly, how can we implement some kind of advertising to generate revenues that will allow the network to grow and expand, and to fund additional content creation. 

We need to answer these questions or this project will only ever be a bunch of us weirdos hanging out on the secret internet.

topic.title: Blocking people is easy.
topic.body:
Does he know? 

Plug qqqqqqqqqqqqqqqq into the search on ZeroId, select mute, and he's done.

topic.title: seed zeronet zites via transmission-daemon
topic.body:
Seed zeronet sites without running zeronet. 

The details are unimportant at this point. Can I seed a zeronet side from my vps using tranmission-daemon? Like a regular torrent? Or is it only possible to seed with the zeronet application itself?

Wat do?

topic.title: How Balkanized has ZeroNet become?
topic.body:
I imagine that there are blocks of users that have created their own imaginary mental islands where only they and few other people that they haven't muted are allowed to exist. 

P2P has just as much potential to be used for the creation of closed off hug-boxes as any other platform.

1568607154_16BaY5JLzzA8TPe4jzXtp3CfZi3Qk.body:
> [undisputed](#comment_1_19MNueeefmtMbBKPCdqtB8UnQmZC8QwLJX): QoS

I googled it for you: 

Port-based rate limiting allows you to limit the speed at which network traffic is sent or received by a device that is connected to a port on your switch. Unlike 802.1p Quality of Service (QoS), port-based rate limiting does not prioritize information based on type. Rate limiting simply means that the switch will slow down traffic on a port to keep it from exceeding the limit that you set. If you set the rate limit on a port too low, you might see degraded video stream quality, sluggish response times during online activity, and other problems.

The best use of rate limiting is to keep low-priority devices that are connected to your switch from using too much of your bandwidth and slowing down your other connected devices. A combination of rate limiting and QoS can help you maximize your networkâ€™s efficiency and prioritize devices and activities.

1568656823_1MfahbRQx2DvKRccN57nhFZvYmfir.body:
> [xcape2net](#comment_386_1GJc2vm4vJjAKsFoFJ2D3gGmKiRac2kfnz): There have already been many discussions about how to make money on ZeroNet.  As you pointed out, the clearnet exists to make money.  And that is what has corrupted it to the point where we are now looking for alternatives.  If ZeroNet expands rapidly and becomes enormous, the same thing will happen to it.  Then, we'll have to go somewhere else.  So, why would you want to hasten the process?  Can't you just be happy making money on the clearnet, and let ZeroNet exist uncorrupted for a while longer?

It's not a matter of me personally making money. The fact is that money (rather, the flow therof) drives progress, development, and the production of interesting content. 

The question I'm interested in answering is deeper. How do we totally divorce the process of development from the thing that has always driven development throughout history? That is money. 

How do you motivate people to abandon the clearnet for better alternative without something to draw them? How do you cause people to dedicate themselves to generating content when there isn't anything in it for them. In the beginning you might draw in a few people who like to make content for the sake of it, but they need to live too. Sooner or later they need to make a buck. 

Even me, I voluntarily seed as much as I can because I am counting on this project becoming more than just a project. It seems that a lot of people just want a cool clubhouse to hang out in.

> [xcape2net](#comment_387_1GJc2vm4vJjAKsFoFJ2D3gGmKiRac2kfnz): What is the point of driving development to something we don't want--something like already exists in the form of the clearnet?  Why would people abandon the clearnet for something just like the clearnet?  What's wrong with a cool clubhouse to hang out in--something similar to the clearnet of the 1990's, before the it became corrupted by money?

Don't get me wrong. I'm not trying to make a moral issue out of it. I'm just thinking aloud. 

I agree that clearnet is certainly corrupted in many ways. But I think that the corruption was caused by a finite number of individuals who used it for personal gain at the expense of everyone else's ability to think, have meaningful conversations, and express their true ideas. I don't see it as a flaw integral to the system itself; the system is merely a series of tubes and boxes to be used one way or another to put it simply. 

I suppose I came here because I view the internet as a tool, as opposed to a source of entertainment. It is a tool that I use to communicate, to be introduced to interesting ideas, and to try to seek the truth of the world through the noise. 

I can see that the question I should have asked is: What do the users of ZeroNet want this place to become?

> [xcape2net](#comment_388_1GJc2vm4vJjAKsFoFJ2D3gGmKiRac2kfnz): I'm sure many would have received something of value from what you said if you had written it in English.  For other peoples' benefit, I'll quote part of it: [...]

I can see that my language has been through a few permutations now. 

What is meant by "rams" when you say "not a place for rams". Obvious It's an animal, but I'm not sure what is meant by the symbolism.

> [tomasz21](#comment_79_1DNH5keUZtST9ACf8Hdre5QzmSGKZh8FRw): Witam na ZeroNet; Po stylu pisania oceniam, Å¼e zrozumiesz co ja pisze. DoÅ¼yliÅ›my takich czasÃ³w Å¼e ludzie siÄ™ wstydzÄ… swojego jÄ™zyka. Ale to nie jest moja sprawa, mogÄ™ pisaÄ‡ w jÄ™zyku angoli, mogÄ™ po niemiecku. MogÄ™ po rosyjsku; Ale piszÄ™ po Polsku. Dlaczego? Bo to jest trudny jÄ™zyk, i trzeba go szanowaÄ‡, a nie poniewieraÄ‡.Jestem od urodzenia oportunistÄ…, i takim zostanÄ™. Nie daÅ‚em siÄ™ sowietom, to i nie dam siÄ™ usmanom, ani czarnogÅ‚owym. Dlatego jestem tutaj w ZeroNecie. Wprowadzenie reklam uwaÅ¼am za bardzo zÅ‚y pomysÅ‚, Wystarczy Å¼e tam jest Acta-2. Åšmieci, i reklamy, i sprzedajna polityka. Tutaj powinno byÄ‡ czysto, i tak powinno pozostaÄ‡. Te miejsce jest dla wolnych ludzi, ktÃ³rzy mogÄ… powiedzieÄ‡ co chcÄ… i majÄ… na myÅ›li, bez Å¼adnej krÄ™pacji. Pozostali do klearnetu  proszÄ™  wypier...Ä‡,  w podskokach, tam jest wasze miejsce. Kontrola i ograniczenia, cenzura i serwery, ktÃ³re moÅ¼na w kaÅ¼dej chwili wyÅ‚Ä…czyÄ‡. Tutaj nie ma miejsca dla pedaÅ‚Ã³w politycznych.ZostaÅ‚o to tak podzielone, i tak niech pozostanie na zawsze.CytujÄ™; WyglÄ…da na to, Å¼e teoretycznie moÅ¼liwe jest, aby caÅ‚y zeronet ostatecznie zostaÅ‚ hostowany przeze mnie lokalnie, w zaleÅ¼noÅ›ci od moich nawykÃ³w uÅ¼ytkowania.Absolutnie nie musisz hostowaÄ‡ caÅ‚ego ZeroNetu. Wystarczy ze zrobisz to ze stronami ktÃ³re lubisz, ktÃ³re siÄ™ tobie podobajÄ…. No chyba Å¼e jesteÅ› pracownikiem sÅ‚uÅ¼b na trzy litery, to wtedy musisz. Taki Å¼art.  [...]

I appreciate you having taken the time to reply so eloquently and completely.

To one of your points: No I am not an official of any kind, although I realize that my question may have carried imperious connotations. I simply meant the question from a practical standpoint - a serious question how the network will expand, and how we can expect to keep content as it ages and looses relevancy.

Additionally, I have no interest in making money through ZeroNet personally. I actually think it will be interesting to see how it unfolds on it's own, without being spurned forward erratically by the whips of corporate interests. I'm merely curious to understand what the creators expect to happen, and how the userbase thinks about the development of this place being divorced from the normal means of expansion, that it, capitalistic means. 

"Niech na talerzu bÄ™dzie maÅ‚o, ale zdrowe i smaczne jedzenie.
Takie dla koneserÃ³w."

I this quote sums up the entire thing nicely. I appreciate your insight, and I have no intention going anywhere.

> [xcape2net](#comment_390_1GJc2vm4vJjAKsFoFJ2D3gGmKiRac2kfnz): By the way, despite the lack of encouragement of commercialism, ZeroNet is growing.  When I first came here in the beginning of April,  I was seeing typically 600 to 1200 peers.  Now I'm seeing 4500 to 6500.   That's an annual growth rate of thousands of percents.  I know the dissolution of 8Chan has something to do with that, and only time will tell if this continues.

It'll be interesting to see what happens what/if infinitychan comes back. I'd be hesitant to go anywhere near it now. Too many oddities surround Jim Watkins.

So it stands to reason that while ZN may be quite active in China, quite a bit of what they discuss remains in China.

> [xcape2net](#comment_404_1GJc2vm4vJjAKsFoFJ2D3gGmKiRac2kfnz): I've heard the phrase, "as above, so below" many times.  Is it a quote from the Bible, or from something more esoteric, like Emanuel Swedenborg or Kabbala?

It's not from the bible directly, although one could argue that it reflects an idea found in the old testament. That is that everything laid out in the old Jewish law was to serve as an earthly reflection of something spiritual or heavenly. I'm just speculating about the connection though. 

I stole this answer from the internet, I didn't write anything below this line: 
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

"Some of the other answers here are pretty solid interpretations. I would offer some practical examples that illustrate the concept.

If you look at your body, you may notice the visual patterns that are reflected (in scale) outside of your body. For instance, the dendritic pattern of your veins & nerve cells is mirrored in rivers & trees (respectively specific). We can look at the number Phi, for instance, and see its role in the proportions of the body (length of fingers, space between eyes, etc). We can look at many patterns within nature and see their correspondence with the body, and to scale from the smallest patterns to the largest ones that we can perceive.

I would say that this is one of my favorite parts about Hermeticism as a philosophy. It enables the interpretation of life through a poetic lens of metaphor and correspondence, and fosters the connection between phenomena across various scales, giving a sense of connection. Perhaps the "biggie" example here would be if we take "As above, so below" and apply it to the existence of consciousness and creativity, then indeed we could follow it all the way up and see that humans are a mirror of Godhead, the singular consciousness and creative potential.

You can apply this axiom in "practice" by considering the larger, or more abstract version of whatever it is that you might be observing or doing, and keeping sight of the implications."

Nothing wrong with choice. But I think that permanently destroying the ability to communicate with another user, where the decision is based on almost zero data, and also cutting yourself off from any ability to ever change your mind about that user is a pretty lousy thing to do. 

In a place like this, we are all we have. So it's better to get along and get to know each other over time, instead of perma-muting other people just because one thing they said rubbed you the wrong way.
